mainClaim: Immigration provides substantial net economic benefits and doesn't harm native workers' wages
evidence: National Academy of Sciences comprehensive study analyzing 40+ years of data found immigration increased U.S. GDP by $2 trillion over 10 years. Native-born workers saw average wage increases of 0.6% due to complementary skills. Immigrants start businesses at twice the rate of native-born Americans, creating 25% more jobs per capita. Areas with higher immigration rates show faster economic growth and innovation.
supportingPoints: Immigrants fill critical labor gaps in healthcare, agriculture, and construction
High-skilled immigration contributes to 30-50% of U.S. innovation and patents
Second-generation immigrants outperform average educational and economic metrics
Immigration helps balance aging demographics in developed nations

authors: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine

limitations: Economic benefits take 10-15 years to fully materialize. Local impacts can vary significantly. Requires investment in integration infrastructure. Benefits strongest with balanced skill distribution among immigrants.
